title.value: Evolution of High Throughput Satellite Systems: Vision, Requirements, and Key Technologies
title.justification: The title of the paper as given in the provided document.
title.quote: Evolution of High Throughput Satellite Systems: Vision, Requirements, and Key Technologies

extractions.description: The paper examines the development and evolution of High Throughput Satellites (HTS), focusing on their current state, challenges, and potential future innovations. It introduces the concept of extremely-high throughput satellites (EHTS) and discusses key technologies, requirements, and visions for the next generation of satellite systems.

type.justification: The paper's focus is on presenting a comprehensive state-of-the-art review, identifying research gaps, discussing key technologies and proposing a vision for future satellite systems without conducting empirical experiments or data analysis.
type.quote: This paper offers a comprehensive state-of-the-art of HTS systems, with a focus on standardization, patents, channel multiple access techniques, routing, load balancing, and the role of software-defined networking (SDN).

name.justification: The paper primarily deals with the evolution, requirements, and future technologies of satellite communication systems, specifically focusing on High Throughput Satellites (HTS) and their envisioned future iterations, Extremely-high Throughput Satellites (EHTS).
name.quote: High throughput satellites (HTS), with their digital payload technology, are expected to play a key role as enablers of the upcoming 6G networks.

name.value: Load Balancing and Quality of Service
name.justification: The sub-research field is covered extensively in the discussion on load balancing, resource allocation, and quality of service (QoS) in HTS.
name.quote: Section VII then turns to load balancing and QoS in HTS, discussing their roles in enhancing HTS efficiency.

name.justification: The paper discusses network routing and scheduling mechanisms in HTS, addressing the challenges and proposing new techniques.
name.quote: Section VI discusses existing routing algorithms for single-beam satellites considering different satellite architectures, recognizing a noticeable gap in the current literature regarding routing mechanisms within HTS systems.

name.justification: The paper examines various multi-channel access techniques like FDMA, TDMA, CDMA, NOMA, and RSMA used in satellite systems, with an emphasis on their application in HTS.
name.quote: In Section V, we summarize the existing multiple-channel access techniques in SatCom.

name.justification: The paper highlights the significant role of SDN in HTS, examining current technologies and their potential impact on future HTS.
name.quote: Section VIII explores the significant role of SDN in HTS, and examines the current SDN technologies in use and their potential impact on future HTS.

name.justification: The paper mentions the use of DRL for dynamic resource allocation (DRA) and beam scheduling in HTS systems.
name.quote: To overcome the limitations of the decision-making optimization problem in DRA and beam scheduling in HTS systems, a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based approach is adopted.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not contribute DRL as a new model but discusses its application in the context of HTS.

name.justification: The DVB-S2X standard is discussed as an evolution of the DVB-S2, particularly relevant for HTS systems.
name.quote: DVB-S2X can be seen as an enhancement of the previous DVB-S2, representing an evolution of the second-generation digital satellite broadcasting system.
